newsitem.title: USA: Pesticides needed for aflatoxin control-researcher.
newsitem.headline: Pesticides needed for aflatoxin control-researcher.

text.p: U.S. researchers have identified four crops that can be protected by pesticides from insects that spread aflatoxin, the National Center for Food and Agricultural Policy said on Monday.
Aflatoxins are carcinogenic chemicals that occur in crops and food infested with a fungus.

Leonard Gianessi, a senior research associate at the center, said field tests showed the level of aflatoxin can be controlled in peanuts, cotton, almonds and corn when the crops are treated with certain insecticides.

The most beneficial insecticides are part of a group known as organophosphates, which is the first group of pesticides to be reviewed by the Environmental Protection Agency under a new federal law to protect food quality, he said.
Some environmentalists have said they would oppose organophosphate insecticides from being licensed by EPA.
"There are some pesticides that protect the public's health. These chemicals have value," Gianessi said.
EPA is scheduled to begin reviewing organophosphate insecticides later this year and will issue a preliminary report on the risks of them in 1998.

In 1977, aflatoxin contaminated nearly two-thirds of the corn grown in the southeastern United States, and in 1988, a Midwestern drought caused aflatoxin to contaminate a large amount of the region's corn crop.

The Food and Drug Administration prohibits human consumption of grain containing more than 20 parts per billion of aflatoxin. Depending on size and breed, farm animals can be fed contaminated grain tested at levels between 20 and 300 parts per billion.
